bestBHT.bht: These quotes provide insights into the interpretation of the relation between kings and the beast. The challenge lies in identifying these kings, particularly due to the brief reigns of certain emperors. The word fallen signifies domination overthrown and empire superseded. These kings represent world-powers, including Rome during John's time. The eighth king can be considered the seventh in one sense, and their rule will be shorter compared to others. This offers comfort to the saints in their sufferings under antichristian states.

Henry Alford: Not, be it noticed, kings over the woman, nor kings of the city symbolized by her: but kings in a totally different relation, viz. that to the beast of which they are heads.
But let the analogy of Scripture and of this book itself guide us, and our way will be clear enough.

I agree with Auberlen, on Daniel, in regarding this seventh as the Christian empire beginning with Constantine: during whose time the beast in his proper essence, in his fulness of opposition to God and his saints, ceases to be.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: they (the seven heads) are seven kings.
Rome was 'the one' existing in John's days.
The time when it is said of it, 'it is not,' is the time during which it is 'wounded to death,' and has the 'deadly wound.'
Albert Barnes: An eighth is mentioned in Revelation 17:11, but it is, at the same time, said that this one so pertains to the seven, or is so properly in one sense of the number seven, though, in another sense, to be regarded as an eighth, that it may be properly reckoned as the seventh.
The notion of ruling, or of authority, is undoubtedly in the word [kings], for the verb βασιλεύω basileuō means 'to rule,' but the word may be applied to anything in which sovereignty resides.

His dominion will be of short duration. It is observable that this characteristic is stated as applicable only to this one of the seven; and the fair meaning would seem to be, that the time would be short as compared with the six that preceded, and as compared with the one that followed - the eighth - into which it was to be merged, Revelation 17:11.
Marvin Vincent: Are fallen [επεσαν] . Lit., fell. Constantly used in the Septuagint of the violent fall or overthrow of kings or kingdoms. See Ezekiel 29:5; Ezekiel 30:6; Isaiah 21:9; Jeremiah 50:15; Jeremiah 51:8.
Philip Schaff: The seven ‘kings’ mentioned are therefore seven world-powers, Egypt, Nineveh, Babylon, Persia, Graecia, Rome, and a power which is to follow the Roman now beheld tottering to its fall.

The word ‘fallen’ is worthy of peculiar notice, for it does not signify mere passing away by such a peaceful death as befell some of those Roman Emperors who are often supposed to be referred to as the ‘seven kings.’
It is a word belonging to domination overthrown, to glory ruined, to empire superseded.
Archibald T. Robertson: The identification of these seven kings is one of the puzzles of the book.
The difficulty about counting these emperors is that Galba, Otho, Vitellius reigned so briefly that they hardly merit being included.
Swete takes this to be Titus, who died September 13, 81, after a short reign.
John Gill: By which are meant not seven ages of the world, as from Adam to Noah; from Noah to Abraham; from Abraham to David; from David to the Babylonish captivity; from the Babylonish captivity to Christ; from Christ to antichrist; and from antichrist to the end of the world; the five first of which were gone in John's time, the sixth was then in being, and when the seventh shall come it will continue for a short time.
But these emperors, though in religion they differed from the others, yet their form of government and title were the same, and therefore must be included in the sixth head.
and this is said for the comfort of the saints, and to keep up their faith and patience under their sufferings in antichristian states.
John Wesley: The prophecy respects the seven hills at the time of the beast, when the Palatine was deserted and the Vatican in use.
Not that the hill was deserted, when another was made the papal residence; but a new one was added to the other sacred palaces.
In this second period, one is, at the same time that the beast is not. Even then there will be a Pope, though not with the power which his predecessors had.

bhtAttempts.bht: These quotes provide insights into the interpretation of Revelation 17:10. The verse refers to kings who are in a different relation to the beast rather than kings over the woman or the city symbolized by her. The identification of these seven kings is challenging, with Galba, Otho, and Vitellius possibly being excluded due to their brief reigns. It is important to note that the word fallen implies more than a peaceful passing away, but rather speaks of domination overthrown and glory ruined. These seven kings are seen as representing seven world-powers, including Rome, which was existing during John's time. The verse also mentions the eighth, who can be properly reckoned as the seventh. The reign of this eighth king will be short, compared to the six that preceded it and the one that follows. The verse provides comfort to the saints, reminding them of the temporary nature of the dominion of antichristian states.

These quotes shed light on the interpretation of a passage regarding kings in relation to the beast. The challenge lies in identifying these kings, particularly due to the brief reigns of Galba, Otho, and Vitellius. The word fallen implies a more significant downfall, representing domination overthrown and empire superseded. These kings symbolize seven world-powers, including Rome in John's time. The eighth king is to be considered the seventh in one sense, and their reign will be short compared to the others. This passage offers comfort to the saints in their sufferings.

These quotes illuminate the interpretation of the relation between kings and the beast. It is difficult to identify these kings, especially considering the brief reigns of Galba, Otho, and Vitellius. The term fallen signifies the overthrow of domination and the ruin of glory. These kings symbolize world-powers, including Rome in John's time. The eighth king can be regarded as the seventh within a certain context, with their rule being shorter compared to the others. This comforts the saints amidst their suffering under antichristian states.
